message: Hi Chloe, great to hear from you - had a lovely thanksgiving and hope you too! And no problem at all, itâ€™s one of the busiest times of the year!Sure, Iâ€™d like that! Next week would be better for me tho (Iâ€™m a bit sick and have family over the weekend). Iâ€™m fairly free except Tuesday evening. Let me know if you have time!And Iâ€™m up for pretty everything! Sure I willï¼I skimmed through those books quickly over the weekend and yesterday I was hidden in my officeâ€™s restroom to search the authorsâ€™s stories lol. Those are fascinating. This is actually my first time reading books by Valerie Solanas and Charlotte Perkins Gilman, so I was really curious to learn more about their backgrounds and what they stood for. Sometimes the context surrounding a bookâ€”like the authorâ€™s perspective and personal life, the historical era, the audienceâ€™s reaction, or even how itâ€™s translated into another languageâ€”can be just as fascinating as the book itself. It usually makes my reading experience more multidimensional and helps me understand the work better.I caught a terrible cold last Saturday so I didnâ€™t make much progress over the weekend beyond coughing and sleeping :( . But I was really happy to receive the paperbacks of Herland and Scum Manifesto! :) I had to replace Scum Manifesto because the cover was damaged, so Iâ€™ve started reading Herland first.Before the paperback arrived, I was reading the Chinese translation of it. In Mandarin, we have different forms of â€˜theyâ€™ depending on genderâ€”â€˜ä»–ä»¬â€™ for males and â€˜å¥¹ä»¬â€™ for females. What really bothered me was that the translator used the male form â€˜ä»–ä»¬â€™ even when referring to an entirely female group. Itâ€™s such an ironic choice in a book like this, as it reinforces the idea of women being treated as the secondary gender.

Thanks for saying thatâ€”itâ€™s okay though! We were able to found some photos online, and they were beautiful. Weâ€™ve decided that next time, weâ€™ll head out of the city to get a better view. Itâ€™s definitely the light pollution was blocking the view.

Please donâ€™t worry about it! I completely understand. I hope youâ€™re having a great time with your family and enjoying the holidays. I do want to apologize for my late replies sometimesâ€”clients have been driving me a bit crazy lately. If I werenâ€™t sitting with my team, Iâ€™d probably be pulling my hair. :p.Itâ€™s always so nice to hear from you, and Iâ€™m really glad we can chat whenever we can. Thank you for being patientï¼
image omitted

I just finished reading Herland! It was such an interesting read. Among the three male characters, I really appreciate that Charlotte chose Van as the main perspective to tell the story. His neutral, observational nature feels the least uncomfortable of the three. Van presents facts without much emotional bias and this personality really align with mine. If his observations had been more comprehensive it wouldâ€™ve been even better.While Jeff has a positive attitude toward women, tends to romanticize and idealize themâ€”placing them on a moral high ground as if theyâ€™re inherently superior. I kinda feel that regardless of gender, this kind of pedestal, though positive, is still a restriction. Itâ€™s like a gilded cage, locking women into unrealistic expectations of perfection. Iâ€™ve noticed this because I also used to have a favorable impression of women and sometimes place similar expectations on them. The downside is that when I meet someone who falls far outside those expectations, it can lead to disappointment. But Iâ€™ve learned to understand and respect the complexity and individuality of different women. Pre-setting these expectations, even if theyâ€™re positive, is still a form of stereotyping.And Terry. ğŸ˜‘ğŸ‘I was rolling my eyes on him whenever he talked. Heâ€™s like one of those typical finance bro with toxic masculinity. I couldnâ€™t even understand why anyone in this womenâ€™s utopia would be attracted to him. His toxic traits are just so overbearing. If the book had expanded on his partnerâ€™s perspective, it wouldâ€™ve been fascinating. I just really curious about what drew her to someone who constantly offended women.

It also made me think about why Charlotte created such a character in the first place.Thereâ€™s a psychological theory that suggests the people you despise often reflect something about yourself or your lived experience. Given her unfortunate childhood and marriageï¼ŒTerry feels like an exaggerated embodiment of her contempt for patriarchal society. His behavior and attitudes amplify how men of her time demeaned, constrained, and controlled women.What really made me laugh were Terry comments about how â€œwomen like to be masteredâ€ or how they supposedly lack that â€œnatural yielding.â€ These ridiculous and inaccurate reflections on women are still so frequent today.

Charlotteâ€™s intent to liberate women as individuals is clear, but this book leans more toward collectivism than individualism. While it mentions encouraging each woman to pursue her own interests, it often feels like individual uniqueness is drowned out by the collective. In the latter part of the book, there are brief references to differences among the three women paired with the male protagonists, but I wish these differences had been explored more deeply. Sometimes those women in this book feel like the same person repeated, especially compared to the distinctly drawn male leads.And about motherhoodâ€”itâ€™s emphasized so heavily throughout the book that it made me wonder Is this focus itself a limitation? While Herland celebrates motherhood as central to society, it still ties womenâ€™s value to nurturing roles. But women arenâ€™t inherently bound to motherhood. Personally I would think Individualism and personal ambition are just as valid to women.

Speaking of competition, my friend and I had a discussion about this while reading the book. Before this book Iâ€™d been reading The Art of War, and one comment stuck with me: â€War is inevitable.â€ It made me wonder are menâ€™s pursuits of brutality, violence, and bloodshed what make it inevitable? My friend argued that competition exists in a female world too. Whenever resources are scarce, conflict will arise. I agree competition is inevitable, but I think women would approach it in a gentler way.I wasnâ€™t very sure so I looked into this. Itâ€™s glad to know that history is full of examples of brilliant female leaders who used collaborative, win-win strategies to resolve resource conflicts. Beyond famous global figures, Iâ€™ve seen this in my managers as well. They sit down, talk things through, and solve problems together and no backstabbing necessary.Iâ€™ve also wondered whether gentler reform methods might slow social progress. But it turns out they donâ€™t lack momentumâ€”they just progress in a more sustainable way.

The relationships in this book are very beautiful and moving. I also loved the emphasis on lifelong learning and self-improvement, which is a theme that runs throughout the story. It reminded me of an interview I once watched with Steve Jobs, where he talked about admiring people who are intelligent and focused on growth, rather than those who get stuck in their egos or caught up defending their pride. This idea of continuous growth felt especially inspiring. Thank you for recommending it!

Btw last time we passed by the 30 Rock Christmas tree, you asked if they use a new tree every year. I looked into it, and yes, they doâ€”this yearâ€™s tree was planted by the Albert family back in 1967 in West Stockbridge, Massachusetts, and they just cut it down. Honestly, it doesnâ€™t feel like the right thing to do and I feel a bit ashamed for never thought about it before. I was just admiring how beautiful it looks.Although the treeâ€™s life was takenï¼Œitâ€™s boosting tourism and supporting local businessesï¼Œwhich helps ensure that some families wonâ€™t be left without a home. And it also bring joy to visitors. I hope this makes the tradition feel a little more valuable , even if itâ€™s not perfect. :( thank you providing such meaningful insight!

So here I am. First things first, are you feeling better? Itâ€™s pretty common to get sick around the end of the year. Hope you were able to rest and take some time off!

Translations are sometimes rushed and donâ€™t pay attention to the nuances of the original version. It indeed seems like the Mandarin translation does not reflect what the book is about: women. We do have a similar rule in French: whenever you refer to a group of persons including at least one man, you will use the male plural form (ils). Thatâ€™s even if you have 30000 women with himâ€¦.
Yes, I really like the front page of this version! Mine was quite different (as I read it in French after finding about it in a Swiss bookshop)
Itâ€™s great that you have a week off; have you made some plans? I hope you were able to rest a bit and enjoy the festivities - New Year must be magic in NYC

Iâ€™m very glad you enjoyed this book - itâ€™s truly amazing when you think that it was written more than 100 years ago. The author was truly ahead of her time! The three characters are pretty well-chosen and balance each others as well. Vanâ€™s observations are neutral, but yet made from the male gaze at the time. The simple fact that these three are pretty adamant on the fact of finding this secret land is, in itself, a truly male endeavor

Perhaps this character is supposed to reflect what was the general view of men on women and to create a continuum of manhood with the womenâ€™s adorer and someone in the middle (Van).It may be that Terry is the embodiment of her personal experience with men and patriarcal society. In any case, the contrasts between the three of them are interesting on how a man may react to women empowerment. Terry would be todayâ€™s INCEL that feels left behind and rightful in his mistreatment of woman (an Andrew Tate), Van the adaptable man and Jeff the causeâ€™s ally

Youâ€™re right to emphasis the collectivist aspect of the book and I think the main idea was to portray a society that is exclusively female as not only being able to function, but to thrive. Perhaps the critique is more geared toward the treatment as a whole, as a social group, rather than on an individual basis. The emphasis on the woman as an individual is a topic that appeared later in the feminist literature (A Room of Oneâ€™s Own by V. Woolf is great btw). Feminist resistance started, in the United States, with demands for equal voting and civic rights. Demands were collective in nature.Donâ€™t you think that the fact that the book shows how truly great a society women can create also celebrates the capacity of individual women? Many women are portrayed in roles that are typically men at that time

Whether violence is a male attribute only is such a fascinating topic. Thereâ€™s a lot of research that has been done about womenâ€™s involvement in the Holocaust and while no German woman was present at the Nuremberg Trial where only main perpetrators were being dealt with, some were tried in court for their complicity. Many said that they had been socialized by men to be violent and therefore they were innocent. Dig further and you will see that some actually found pleasure in torturing and witnessing acts of torture and violence.
Tis is so so cool! Way better than any other Xmas tree and carbon-free!! Thanks for sharing!
I love it! And your writing is not bad at all! When would you use the third saying and not the second or vice-versa? Is one more appropriate than the other in certain situations?

A few snapshots of the past few days
Hey Tamaraï¼Good afternoonï¼Œthank you for askingï¼I got full recovery last week and had a great holiday with my friends.

During the holidays my friends and I decided to try something funâ€”do whatever comes to mind at that moment. It all started when we planned to go skiing in Vermont. We rented a car but totally forgot to book a place to stay and two of my friend even completely forgot we had plans. At the very last minute we switched plans and decided to go to Catamount instead. The night before, we rushed to buy all the ski gear and somehow managed to get tickets. After a few triumphant laps on the bunny hill (where I obviously mastered the art of looking like I know what Iâ€™m doing), I very confidently decided it was time for the green trail. Spoiler: I wasnâ€™t. I ended up falling about a dozen times, and most of my energy went into figuring out how to stand back upâ€”apparently, thatâ€™s the real workout. But it was so much fun that Iâ€™m already thinking of going skiing again next monthThis one spontaneous decision turned out so fun and exciting that we decided to embrace this impulsive spirit for the whole holiday. We ended up doing so many things completely on a whimâ€”it was such a refreshing and thrilling way to spend the break! I cook New Yearâ€™s Eve dinner for my friend and I decided to learn how to make Tiramisu one day before the dinner and successfully made it. The final menu was determined on my way to grocery shopping. We just randomly brainstormed what we wanted to eat.Yesterday afternoon we were watching the movie Chicago, and halfway through, we decided why not go see it live on Broadway? So we booked tickets last-minute and ended up with front-row seats! The performance was absolutely stunningâ€”the dancing and singing were so powerful, moving, and beautifulï¼ï¼ï¼At the end, when Roxie was throwing roses, she looked right in our direction, but we werenâ€™t able to catch that one. Itâ€™s been so much fun. No overthinking, no meticulous planningâ€”just going with the flow and seeing where it takes you. It feels freeing, exciting, and a little chaotic for sure. Have you ever done anything like that?

Thank you so much for sharing those photosï¼theyâ€™re really beautiful! When you mentioned snow in Switzerland a few days ago, I actually wanted to ask if you could take some photos, but I didnâ€™t want to bother you. Appreciate itï¼How was your holiday? Did you do anything fun or exciting with your familyï¼ŸOr maybe read any interesting book?
Howâ€™s the cover of your book look likeï¼ŸThere are several versions of front page on Amazon and I feel this one mostly align with the theme of Herland, full of colorï¼Œvitality and seriousness.

Thatâ€™s indeed very annoying and we see this issue across different languages. I noted that there is a gender-neutral pronoun in French ï¼ˆielï¼‰ï¼Œis this widely usedï¼ŸJust curious whether gender-neutral language becoming more common in French and German these years. This book was translated into Chinese in 2015 and we have only started to use TA ï¼ˆtheyï¼‰in casual writing as a gender-neutral option since 2020. Itâ€™s not official but I do hope itâ€™s a step toward inclusivity. Btw I do have a stupid questionï¼Œcould international law push for more gender-neutral language in places where gendered forms dominateï¼Ÿ

Sharing some photos of New Year in NYC. ï¼šï¼‰New Yearâ€™s vibe in New York was incredibly lively ï¼ˆalso extremely crowdedï¼‰I spent most of the time hanging out with my friend so took extra 2 days off to have do some reading and cooking.

Thatâ€™s a fascinating observation! Their ï¼ˆthe three male charactersï¼‰relentless pursuit of discovering this secret land does feel very much like a traditionally male narrative of conquest and exploration. Itâ€™s interesting when compare their behavior with the society they find in Herland. The women in the book donâ€™t pursue or conquer in the same wayâ€”they build, nurture, and sustain. I really like how those womenâ€™s enthusiasm in learning and growing. Life to them was growth; their pleasure was in growing, and their duty also. They grew together-not by competition, but by united action. <This message was edited>

You made a great pointï¼Herland truly does portray a thriving, exclusively female society as a collective whole, and your insights have given me a fresh perspective on how to interpret that. I used to see the lack of emphasis on individual women in Herland as a limitation, but now youâ€™ve mentioned it I can see how it aligns with the priorities of its timeâ€”a response to systemic inequality through collective solidarity and I can see how the collective achievements are rooted in womenâ€™s individual strength and competence.Thank you for sharing such thoughtful ideas. Iâ€™m also looking forward to exploring V. Woolfâ€™s works now.

Thank you! Iâ€™m glad you liked it. To answer your question, the third one, ä¸‡äº‹å¦‚æ„ (May everything go your way), is a bit more formal and broad, so itâ€™s often used in written greetings or with people you want to show respect to, like elders or colleagues. The second one, å¿ƒæƒ³äº‹æˆ (May all your wishes come true), feels more personal and is commonly used with friends and family to wish them success with their specific goals. æ–°å¹´å¿«ä¹ is the most universal and safe to use with anyoneâ€”itâ€™s straightforward and fits all contexts. Also thank you for saying thatï¼Compared to my mom, mine definitely doesnâ€™t measure up. When I mentioned my handwriting was bad and you asked if Iâ€™d ever practiced, it made me realize some things Iâ€™m not good at arenâ€™t about talentâ€”theyâ€™re about effort. Since then Iâ€™ve started writing something every day, and itâ€™s been satisfying to see small improvements. Itâ€™s also about using little psychology trick to keep myself motivatedâ€”reminding myself that if I think Iâ€™m bad at something, I can always stay desired to improve with consistent effort.Speaking of psychology, thereâ€™s a concept called â€œwise interventionsâ€ from social psychology that focuses on improving certain aspects of life by making small but meaningful adjustments to our mindset and actions. Iâ€™ve found this surprisingly effective. Last time you mentioned how pursuing a PhD can feel overwhelming sometimes due to the long journey ahead, and I can really relate. Adjusting mindset and celebrating small wins helps a lot when I faced similar issues. Even tiny steps, like reading for just three minutes, add up over time and contribute to progress. When we achieve small wins, our brain releases dopamineâ€”the â€œfeel-goodâ€ chemical. This reinforces positive behavior and creates a reward loop, which can make us more likely to keep going. Itâ€™s almost like training our mind to associate effort with satisfaction, even if the ultimate goal feels far away. Hope this perspective is helpful. Also, Iâ€™m very sorry my responses can be a bit on and off sometimes. I had limited time to check my phone over the past few days but I donâ€™t like replying in a hurry, so I wait for longer time windows to read your messages and respond thoughtfully. Take careï¼

You could make a novel out of it. I could imagine it being titled â€œvivre dans lâ€™instant prÃ©sentâ€ (to give a pedantic French touch ;))Joke apart, Iâ€™m very glad you enjoyed your first ski experience despite a few bumps. Iâ€™ve been skiing since Iâ€™m five and itâ€™s more often than I would like to admit it that I end on my butt. But as you said, itâ€™s part of the experience! It also seems like you had a very exciting winter break! Itâ€™s very nice not to always plan out things and go with the wind.To be honest, most of my activities are planned in advance unfortunately. Iâ€™m a bit of a control freak and the simple idea of not knowing where Iâ€™m going to sleep scares me. Also, Iâ€™ve always lived far away from my close friends I could imagine doing such things with - when meeting someone takes you a 1.5h commute, planing ahead is almost mandatory

Oh, please ask! Iâ€™m happy to share some pictures! Unfortunately, the snow is gone now and itâ€™s been raining quite a lot. Hopefully, it will be back this weekend.My holidays have been great, thanks! Iâ€™ve forced myself to take some time off and spent a lot of time going on walks in the mountains with my parents and friends. The festivities also kept me occupied a great deal! Iâ€™ve been reading quite a lot as well; currently reading Dune

These gendered languages drive me mad! The iel pronoun would would work but its use is still a niche thing. Itâ€™s not recognized by the French academy. Itâ€™s also difficult to use in sentences in which thereâ€™s an adjective. If you translate theyâ€™re good looking, youâ€™d have â€œiels sont beaux.ellesâ€. Iâ€™m glad efforts are being made in China about it. How are laws formulated? In a neutral way?Itâ€™s a good question. If worded in a certain way, international legal norms (comprised in treaties and legal texts) could help spread the use of non-gendered formulations.
They look great! I see that the lights are still on and the streets look festive! What have you been reading these days?

One could read in the authorâ€™s choice of narrating perspective almost an equation of the male personality with broader patterns in male-dominated societies, incl. colonization etc. I wonder if she had a particular stance on that
I just did a quick search about it and Perkins appears to be a contested figure, especially because of her writings during the segregation period. Iâ€™ll have to look into it a bit more

Completely agree! Many gendered language is so deeply rooted in bias and frustratingly unfair. Itâ€™s great to see progress in French, even with its challenges. Thanks for explaining how it works btwï¼In China, promoting gender-neutral language hasnâ€™t really come from legislation. Very unfortunately, laws still tend to reflect the male-dominated political system, though thereâ€™s slow progress. Yijiao and I have had many discussions about how frustrating this is. She understands this far better than I do and has a very impressive way of thinking logically through these issues. The shift toward gender-neutral terms has driven more by feminist movements over the past decade, amplified by social media. One incident that gained attention involved a prominent female author who repeatedly expressed that using male-specific terms for women is disrespectful. Despite her objections, she was still officially addressed with a male honorific, sparking widespread discussions. This eventually encouraged more people to avoid male-centered language and promote inclusivity. Recently, thereâ€™s even been a push to emphasize å¥¹ ï¼ˆsheï¼‰over ä»– ï¼ˆheï¼‰to flip the focus. itâ€™s hard to say which approach will have a bigger impactItâ€™s exciting to think about how international law could support these changes globally. We both strongly agree that having women involved in shaping legal systems or taking on leadership roles is so important. Iceland is such an inspiring example. Itâ€™s amazing to see what a female-led government can achieve.

Itâ€™s fascinating that Gilmanâ€™s idea of a thriving, female-dominated society is actually supported by plenty of data and real-world examples nowadays. I admire how forward-thinking she was, especially considering the era she lived. Iâ€™ve found that female-led environments place more emphasis on collaboration, emotional safety, and understanding. Many male managers just push their own preferred methods or say â€œJust do it,â€ whereas female leaders tend to listen, clarify their goals and expectations, and offer encouragement throughout. It just feels so right not to be around any males. :pGiven her own experiences and background, itâ€™s no surprise that Gilmanâ€™s perspective is both complex and insightful. Another book of hers, The Yellow Wallpaper, is also interesting for how it addresses womenâ€™s mental health and societal roles.
